author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Ellen Ash Peters, Pioneer on the Connecticut Bench, Dies at 94
description: The first woman on the faculty of Yale Law School, she was named to the State Supreme Court in 1978 and became its first female chief justice six years later.
content: Ellen Ash Peters, a legal trailblazer who was the first woman on the faculty of Yale Law School and the first female chief justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, and who wrote a landmark civil rights decision in 1996 desegregating public schools in Hartford, died on Wednesday at her home in West Hartford. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Deadly Israeli Airstrikes Again Hit Rafah
description: For weeks, Palestinians have been bracing for a ground offensive on the southern Gaza city, where over one million displaced people have fled.
content: Israeli airstrikes on the southern Gaza city of Rafah on Saturday killed several civilians, including women and children, according to Palestinian state media, sending more fear through an area where over one million displaced Palestinians are crowded into tents and temporary quarters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Bill to Limit Canada’s Trade Negotiators on Farm Goods Edges Nearer to Law
description: The measure from a member of the Bloc Québécois would ban changes to the supply management system for dairy, poultry and eggs.
content: Private members’ bills, particularly those from members of the Bloc Québécois, rarely make their way through the parliamentary process. But after passing the House of Commons with strong support from members of all parties, a bill from Yves Perron, who speaks for the Bloc on farming, handily passed a second vote in the unelected Senate on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: 3 Officers Face Charges in Death of California Man Who Was Pinned Down
description: The officers, all with the Alameda Police Department at the time, were charged with involuntary manslaughter after the district attorney reopened the case.
content: Three years after police officers in Northern California pinned a man face down for about five minutes as he begged for relief, prosecutors announced that the officers would face charges of involuntary manslaughter in the man’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Jack Healy
title: Bucking Trump, Anti-Abortion Movement Shows Deep Roots in Arizona
description: Even as abortion rights ballot issues have had some striking successes, anti-abortion forces have stood firm in state legislatures like Arizona’s where they have deep convictions and positions of power.
content: Speaker Ben Toma walked off the floor of the Arizona House of Representatives, resolute — if stressed — after he cast the pivotal vote to again block an effort to repeal the state’s 1864 abortion ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: In Late-Stage Budget Talks, Hochul Wins Concessions From N.Y. Lawmakers
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul used the $237 billion budget to wedge in contentious issues like extending Mayor Eric Adams’s control over New York City schools.
content: In the days approaching April 1, the corridors and backrooms of the New York State Capitol tend to be filled with tension and chaos, as the governor, lawmakers and staff scramble to meet the deadline to pass a state budget that is as much a policy blueprint as it is a spending plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sentimental Feelings
description: Garrett Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley’s puzzle is inviting without being too forward.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is neat; it’s Garret Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley’s third daily Times collaboration, after a Monday grid in January and a Tuesday puzzle in March. That’s a blistering pace and implies a level of closeness that I think I can sense in today’s clues. There’s a kind of riffing humor throughout. A single pun about mingling, say, spins off into other relevant jokes about love and marriage. There’s also a lot of interesting trivia and a meta touch, a clue that solved to the name of a type of wordplay that I like. This surprised me (which I also liked).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Do Tanks Have a Place in 21st-Century Warfare?
description: As explosive drones gain battlefield prominence, even the mighty U.S. Abrams tank is increasingly vulnerable.
content: The drone combat in Ukraine that is transforming modern warfare has begun taking a deadly toll on one of the most powerful symbols of American military might — the tank — and threatening to rewrite how it will be used in future conflicts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Michael Gold
title: Ukraine Aid Divides Republicans, After Trump Tones Down His Resistance
description: His most vocal allies in the House, however, were loudly against providing assistance as Ukraine fights Russia’s invasion.
content: The House vote on Saturday to provide $61 billion in American aid to Ukraine was the clearest sign yet that at least on foreign policy, the Republican Party is not fully aligned with former President Donald J. Trump and his “America First” movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Lasers, Inflatable Dancers and the Fight to Fend Off Avian Flu
description: Some poultry growers are turning to innovative tactics to protect their flocks, deploying deterrents like drones, air horns, balloons and decoy predators.
content: Loren Brey, a poultry grower in Minnesota, walked onto the farm where his egg-laying turkeys nest in November to discover a handful of hens, dead from the highly pathogenic avian flu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Eliza Fawcett
title: At Least 2 Are Stabbed on a Party Boat in Brooklyn
description: Three people were hospitalized, including a man who was struck in the head with a bottle, and more than 1,000 passengers were evacuated, the authorities said.
content: Two men were stabbed and another was hit in the head with a bottle on a crowded party boat in Brooklyn on Saturday evening, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Melania’s Trials
description: The former first lady is swept back into the Stormy cyclone.
content: Outside my office, there is a picture of the Slovenian Sphinx visiting the Egyptian Sphinx, taken during a 2018 photo shoot in Giza, nine months after Melania Trump was blindsided by the steamy news about her husband and Stormy Daniels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: ‘Aging in Place, or Stuck in Place?’
description: Homeownership is not the boon to older Americans that it once was.
content: When it came to housing, Susan Apel and Keith Irwin thought they had planned adroitly for later life. They bought a four-bedroom house on two acres in Lebanon, N.H., 24 years ago, and “we made sure to pay off the mortgage before we retired,” said Ms. Apel, 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Stereophonic’ Review: Hitmakers Rendered in Sublime Detail
description: In David Adjmi’s new play, with songs by Will Butler, a ’70s band’s success breeds tension, and punches up the volume on Broadway.
content: Peering behind the mystique of rock ’n’ roll has undeniable voyeuristic appeal. So there is an immediate thrill to seeing the mahogany-paneled control room and glassed-in sound booth that fill the Golden Theater stage, where “Stereophonic” opened on Friday. But David Adjmi’s astonishing new play, with songs by the former Arcade Fire member Will Butler, delivers far more than a dishy glimpse inside the recording studio during rock’s golden age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Get Cracking
description: Looking for an intricate diversion? Pick this puzzle by Michael Schlossberg — what’s inside pays off.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Martin Wygod, a Winner on Wall Street and the Racetrack, Dies at 84
description: After he made a fortune selling prescription drugs and providing medical information online, he and his wife became leading breeders of thoroughbred horses.
content: Martin J. Wygod, a Wall Street whiz who graduated from walking horses after races to owning and breeding championship thoroughbreds when he made millions from investing in online companies that sold pharmaceuticals by mail and pruned medical paperwork, died on April 12 in San Diego. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Original ‘Star Trek’ Enterprise Model Is Found After Being Missing for Decades
description: The 33-inch model surfaced on eBay after disappearing around 1979. An auction house is giving it to the son of Gene Roddenberry, the creator of “Star Trek.”
content: The first model of the U.S.S. Enterprise, the starship that appeared in the opening credits of the original “Star Trek” television series, has been returned to Eugene Roddenberry Jr., the son of the creator of the series, decades after it went missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: April Showers Bring Sopa de Fideos
description: Rick Martínez’s fast recipe for sopa de fideos y frijoles con chorizo (fideo and bean soup with chorizo) is the dinner to tuck into when skies are gray.
content: Just in time for longer evenings, bodega flowers and all the green vegetables: My colleagues Tanya Sichynsky and Krysten Chambrot have a wonderful new interactive guide to spring entertaining, a choose-your-own-adventure for dinner-party planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Anna Betts
title: Columbia Students Arrested Over Campus Rally May Face Other Consequences
description: Students who camped in tents to protest the war in Gaza, including the daughter of Representative Ilhan Omar, may be barred from finishing the semester.
content: Many of the more than 100 Columbia University and Barnard College students who were arrested after refusing to leave a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus on Thursday woke up to a chilly new reality this week: Columbia said that their IDs would soon stop working, and some of them would not be able to finish the semester.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: You Finished I.V.F. and Want to Donate Embryos. Is There a Tax Benefit?
description: Some people may consider donating embryos to researchers in light of Alabama’s I.V.F. ruling and in advance of other state actions. Would it be considered a charitable gift?
content: The Alabama Supreme Court’s in vitro fertilization ruling this year, which held that frozen embryos should be considered children, raised a long list of questions for people worried about their future fertility treatments. My colleague Tara Siegel Bernard and I attempted to answer many of them in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larissa Anderson, Alex Barron, Kate LoPresti, Wendy Dorr, Corey Schreppel and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Taylor Swift’s New Album Reviewed
description: Our pop music critic on “The Tortured Poets Department.”
content: On Friday, Taylor Swift released her 11th studio album, “The Tortured Poets Department.” Two hours after the initial release at midnight, she announced a second volume of the album, bringing the number of new songs to 31.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Being Friends May Manifest as Winning on the Court
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 20, 2024.
content: “We low-key hate each other, but we like each other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattie Kahn
title: A Sugary Bonbon of a Novel From a Legendary Foodie
description: In “The Paris Novel,” Ruth Reichl is a glutton for wish fulfillment.
content: Stella St. Vincent’s estranged mother dies and leaves her with an unusual bequest: She is to take her modest inheritance and go to Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Shapiro
title: What Began as a War on Theater Won’t End There
description: The current politically-driven suppression of theater productions in high schools has a grim historical precedent.
content: Productions of plays in America’s high schools have been increasingly under attack. In 2023, Anton Chekhov’s “Three Sisters” was rejected in Tennessee (since it deals with adultery); “August: Osage County,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Tracy Letts, was canceled in Iowa after rehearsals had begun (the community was deemed not ready for it); and in Kansas, students were not even allowed to study, let alone stage, “The Laramie Project,” a play by Moisés Kaufman and members of the Tectonic Theater Project about the murder of a gay student, Matthew Shepard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Archie Moore, Australian Artist, Wins Top Prize at Venice Biennale
description: Moore, an Indigenous Australian artist, won the Golden Lion for “kith and kin,” which draws on what he says is 65,000 years of family history.
content: Archie Moore, an Indigenous Australian artist who has created an installation including a monumental family tree, won the top prize at the Venice Biennale on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: How R.F.K. Jr. Got on the Michigan Ballot, With Only Two Votes
description: The independent candidate persuaded a tiny party to give him its line on the ballot in a key 2024 battleground state, sparing him a costly, arduous organizing effort.
content: In January, when Doug Dern, the state chairman of the Natural Law Party of Michigan, got an email from a top strategist for Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign, he sensed it could be a star turn for his tiny political group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Most Important Thing I Teach My Students Isn’t on the Syllabus
description: Humility can be a bulwark against arrogance, absolutism, purity and zeal, and an antidote in our age of grievance.
content: I warn my students. At the start of every semester, on the first day of every course, I confess to certain passions and quirks and tell them to be ready: I’m a stickler for correct grammar, spelling and the like, so if they don’t have it in them to care about and patrol for such errors, they probably won’t end up with the grade they’re after. I want to hear everyone’s voice — I tell them that, too — but I don’t want to hear anybody’s voice so often and so loudly that the other voices don’t have a chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ségolène Le Stradic
title: A Turbocharged Croissant Delights (and Disturbs) Paris
description: Stéphane Louvard married one of his signature croissants with a chocolate chip cookie to come up with the “crookie.” After a slow start, his creation took off after it became a TikTok phenomenon.
content: All it took for the crookie to take shape was a baker looking for a diversion, his time-tested croissant recipe and a few cookies for inspiration. It took TikTok to make it go viral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Ferguson
title: A Ragtag Resistance Sees the Tide Turning in a Forgotten War
description: Rebel fighters have handed Myanmar’s army defeat after defeat, for the first time raising the possibility that the military junta could be at risk of collapse.
content: The night Ma Suu Kyi thought she would die of her wounds on the front lines of a forgotten war, a crescent moon hung overhead. A pendant of the Virgin Mary dangled around her neck. Maybe those augurs saved her. Or maybe, she said, it was not yet time for her to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: VW Workers in Tennessee Vote for Union, a Labor Milestone
description: The Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga is set to become the first unionized auto factory in the South not owned by one of Detroit’s Big Three.
content: In a landmark victory for organized labor, workers at a Volkswagen plant in Tennessee have voted overwhelmingly to join the United Automobile Workers union, becoming the first nonunion auto plant in a Southern state to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: It’s 4/20. These Restaurants Know You Have the Munchies.
description: The stoner celebration is becoming a national food holiday, thanks in part to marketing initiatives from Jimmy John’s, KFC, Wingstop and others.
content: This weekend, Alamo Drafthouse Cinemas across the country, temporarily renamed Alamo Dankhouse, are mixing Chex cereal, cheese balls and ranch seasoning with buttered popcorn. The snack is the first of three courses in a special menu that will be served during screenings of stoner classics like “Inherent Vice” and “The Beach Bum.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Seemed Like a Good Idea at the Time
description: Stories that begin full of hope — then take a turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Roman Gabriel, Star Quarterback of the 1960s and ’70s, Dies at 83
description: In 16 seasons with the Los Angeles Rams and the Philadelphia Eagles, he played in four Pro Bowl games and was voted Most Valuable Player in 1969.
content: Roman Gabriel, one of the leading pro football passers of his time, who complemented his rocket arm with an imposing physique over 16 seasons beginning in 1962, died on Saturday at his home in Little River, S.C. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: David H. Pryor, Arkansas Senator and Clinton Ally, Dies at 89
description: During his 34 years as an elected official, Mr. Pryor was sometimes said to be more liberal, especially on racial issues, than the people who elected him.
content: David H. Pryor, a liberal Democrat who won two terms as governor of Arkansas and three in the United States Senate, and who paved the way for the political rise of his young ally Bill Clinton in an era of changing racial attitudes in the South, died on Saturday at his home in Little Rock. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Lauren Herstik
title: A Man Hailed as Cindy Birdsong’s Rescuer Is Accused of Exploiting Her
description: The son of the former Supreme says in court papers that the man who sought to help his mother after she became incapacitated also took advantage of her financially.
content: Just last year, Brad Herman, a longtime behind-the-scenes aide to celebrities, drew praise from the family of Cindy Birdsong, an ailing former member of the Supremes. He was credited with helping to rescue her from what they described as a friend’s undue influence over her care and finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Bedtime Stories for Grown-Ups
description: For those past the age of a parental tuck-in, audiobooks might provide a soothing analogue.
content: If I’m not working or around other people, more often than not, I want to be reading. The rise in availability of audiobooks has made this easier to achieve. One can read a physical book when stationary, then listen to an audiobook when driving, tidying up, walking or otherwise in motion. I like to get the same book in both formats for complete immersion: read the book over breakfast, switch to the audiobook on the stereo while getting ready for work, listen on headphones during my commute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: No, Your Spaghetti Doesn’t Have to Be al Dente: 5 Pasta Myths, Debunked
description: A veteran food journalist settles some long-simmering disputes on a slippery subject.
content: After publishing an article debunking five commonly held kitchen myths last week, I got questions — and a surprising number of pleas — about pasta. I was asked to settle long-simmering disputes between grandparents and grandchildren, roommates, and husbands and wives of 50-plus years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: The Town at the Center of a Supreme Court Battle Over Homelessness
description: A lawsuit by a group of homeless residents of a small Oregon town could reshape the way cities across the country deal with homelessness.
content: Inside a warming shelter, Laura Gutowski detailed how her life had changed since she became homeless two and a half years ago in Grants Pass, a former timber hub in the foothills of southern Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: When Pregnant Patients ‘Become Radioactive to Emergency Departments’
description: Exceptions to abortion bans aren’t worth the paper they’re printed on.
content: I thought I would follow up my Tuesday column on abortion rights with this report from The Associated Press, on the state of emergency services for pregnant women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Pence
title: Mike Pence: Donald Trump Has Betrayed the Pro-Life Movement
description: Here’s how America should build on the end of Roe v. Wade
content: Serving as vice president in the most pro-life administration in American history was one of the greatest honors of my life. Of all our accomplishments, I am perhaps most proud that the Supreme Court justices we confirmed voted to send Roe v. Wade to the ash heap of history, ending a travesty of jurisprudence that led to the death of more than 63 million unborn Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Why Myanmar’s War Matters, Even if the World Isn’t Watching
description: A devastating, yearslong civil war is heating up, but it still hasn’t attracted broad international notice.
content: An escalating civil war threatens to break apart a country of roughly 55 million people that sits between China and India. That has international consequences, but the conflict hasn’t commanded wide attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
title: Top Chinese Swimmers Tested Positive for Banned Drug, Then Won Olympic Gold
description: The case, involving multiple swimmers who seven months later won medals at the 2021 Games, prompted accusations of a cover-up and concerns over why antidoping regulators chose not to intervene.
content: Twenty-three top Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance seven months before the Tokyo Olympic Games in 2021 but were allowed to escape public scrutiny and continue to compete after top Chinese officials secretly cleared them of doping and the global authority charged with policing drugs in sports chose not to intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: The ‘Amityville’ Horrors Keep Coming
description: The famed “Amityville Horror” film has spawned at least 45 sequels. A look at why the Amityville name has endured in the horror genre.
content: When it comes to large film franchises, a few titans emerge: Godzilla, James Bond, Spider-Man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: CNN’s Coverage of Man Who Set Himself on Fire Shows Challenges of Live News
description: There was both praise and criticism of the legal analyst and anchor, Laura Coates, and the network’s split-second decision to show the graphic footage.
content: Until Friday, at least, the cable news coverage of the first criminal trial of a former president carried a hint of anticlimax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Strikes an Iranian Military Base, but Damage Appears Limited
description: The drone attack may have been launched from inside Iran, once again demonstrating Israel’s ability to carry out clandestine operations there.
content: The Israeli military struck Iran early on Friday in retaliation for an aerial attack on Israel last weekend, according to two Israeli and three Iranian officials, but the strike appeared to be limited in scope and the reaction from both Israel and Iran was muted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Adrienne Grunwald
title: A Holiday for Weed Fans, Complete With Sponsors
description: With the legalization of marijuana in New York, celebrations of “4/20” have gone mainstream.
content: In the culture of cannabis, April 20 is a holiday when those who partake light up in enjoyment and in protest of prohibition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Kidney Donors Be Paid?
description: A guest essay argued in favor of payments. Readers, including donors, offer divergent views.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Lily Gladstone and Riley Keough Investigate a Chilling Murder
description: In a joint interview, the actors discuss “Under the Bridge,” their new true-crime series based on a teenager’s brutal killing in British Columbia.
content: “We’ve been teenage girls,” Lily Gladstone said. Which means that Gladstone and her co-star, Riley Keough, know what teenage girls can do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samanth Subramanian
title: Time Is Running Out for Rahul Gandhi’s Vision for India
description: But in this year’s elections, the scion of India’s most storied political family is still trying to unseat Modi — and change the nation’s course.
content: Rahul Gandhi stood in a red Jeep, amid a churning crowd in Varanasi, trying to unseat the Indian government with a microphone in his hand. “The mic isn’t good,” he said. “Please quiet down and listen.” It was the morning of Feb. 17 — Day 35 of a journey that began in the hills of Manipur, in India’s northeast, and would end by the ocean in Mumbai, in mid-March. In total, Gandhi would cover 15 states and 4,100 miles, traveling across a country that once voted for his party, the Indian National Congress, almost by reflex. No longer, though. For a decade, the Congress Party has been so deep in the political wilderness, occupying fewer than a tenth of the seats in Parliament, that even its well-wishers wonder if Gandhi is merely the custodian of its end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Knopper
title: Distracted at the Tea Ceremony
description: It’s not easy to find serenity when memories come flooding in.
content: My fiancée, Meredith, and I were sitting crossed-legged on cushions around a low wooden table with the tea ceremonialist and two other young women. Now and then, a gray cat jumped onto our laps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: How Ozempic Is Transforming a Small Danish Town
description: In Kalundborg, population under 17,000, Novo Nordisk is making huge investments to increase production of its popular diabetes and weight-loss drugs, Ozempic and Wegovy.
content: As the sun sets over the harbor in Kalundborg, a small town about 60 miles west of Copenhagen, light streams through the glass walls of Shaun Gamble’s cafe and bathes his afternoon customers in a warm glow. It’s an enviable location — on the water, next to a large playground — except for the fact that little else is nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Say Hello to Your Addiction Risk Score — Courtesy of the Tech Industry
description: A number of new tech companies want to solve the opioid crisis with algorithms. It’s a flawed and potentially harmful proposition.
content: Before Dr. Bobby Mukkamala — an ear, nose, and throat specialist in Michigan — prescribed post-surgical opioids recently, he checked state records of his patient’s existing controlled substance prescriptions, as legally required. A score generated by a proprietary algorithm appeared on his screen. Known as NarxCare — and now used by most state prescription monitoring databases, major hospitals and pharmacy chains — the algorithm indicated his patient had an elevated risk of developing an addiction to opioid painkillers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Americans’ New TV Habit: Subscribe. Watch. Cancel. Repeat.
description: Many more people are jumping from one streaming subscription to another, a behavior that could have big implications for the entertainment industry.
content: Early last year, Josh Meisel and his wife wanted to watch a new buzzy Peacock drama, “Poker Face,” starring Natasha Lyonne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson, Tracey Tully and Jan Ransom
title: A Life Overtaken by Conspiracy Theories Explodes in Flames as the Public Looks On
description: Friends of Max Azzarello, who set himself on fire outside Donald J. Trump’s trial, said he was a caring person whose paranoia had led him down a dark path.
content: The journey that ended with a man setting himself on fire on Friday outside the Manhattan courthouse where Donald J. Trump was being tried seemed to have begun in Florida, with a series of increasingly bizarre outbursts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Co-op Assessments: Do You Have to Pay What They Say?
description: Courts allow co-op boards significant power over building finances, including assessments — if the fees are in ‘good faith.’
content: Q: I am a shareholder in a Riverdale co-op, and the board recently announced a $500,000 assessment that must be paid over the next three years. Based on my calculation, on average, each shareholder will be charged $5,000. The board said the assessments were needed to cover repairs and new city mandates, but was vague about how the $500,000 figure was calculated. The proprietary lease and bylaws don’t give the board specific authority to impose assessments, but they do allow the board to set maintenance payments and cash requirements. Is there any way to challenge this assessment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Tania Ganguli and Sarah Kessler
title: Can the W.N.B.A. Make Money?
description: A wave of star power has lifted hopes that viewership will pick up for the women’s league.
content: After the Indiana Fever made Caitlin Clark the W.N.B.A.’s No. 1 draft pick this week, the team’s ticket prices soared. The basketball star’s long-distance shots and huge following have landed her on “Saturday Night Live,” attracted interest from sponsors like Nike and sold out jerseys at a rapid pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: U.S.C. Cut the Valedictorian’s Graduation Speech. Now, the Celebrities Are Out, Too.
description: Jon M. Chu, the director of “Crazy Rich Asians,” and Billie Jean King were set to be among the featured guests.
content: The University of Southern California, reeling after a controversy over its valedictorian selection, announced Friday that its main commencement program would eliminate outside speakers and honorees, including the director of “Crazy Rich Asians,” Jon M. Chu, and the tennis star Billie Jean King.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Luke Broadwater
title: Senate Passes Two-Year Extension of Surveillance Law Just After It Expired
description: The law lapsed only briefly after a late-night deal that allowed votes on privacy advocates’ proposed changes, all of which were defeated.
content: The Senate early on Saturday approved an extension of a warrantless surveillance law, moving to renew it shortly after it had expired and sending President Biden legislation that national security officials say is crucial to fighting terrorism but that privacy advocates decry as a threat to Americans’ rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Judith Hill Sang With Pop Royalty. Now She Is Composing Her Own Story.
description: The singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist was close to Michael Jackson and Prince. After their deaths, her world crumbled and she had to rebuild on her own.
content: The first time the musician Judith Hill performed her anguished requiem “Black Widow” for an audience, she wept, right onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How New Wars Have Brought Back Old American Divisions
description: Both parties experience echoes of decades past.
content: For all the ways that our political coalitions have changed over the last few generations — Southern Democrats joining the G.O.P., Northeastern Republicans turning Democrat, “Reagan Democrats” moving right, suburban Republicans voting for Joe Biden — there are patterns that persist across the generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Inge Oosterhoff
title: How a Dating Show Host Spends Her Sundays
description: Stef Dag, host of “Hot & Single,” goes cafe-hopping with friends, boxes in the park and gets ready for a comedy set at The Stand.
content: Stef Dag, a 28-year-old comedian, is slightly cynical but also hopeful about finding love in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Strike Was Meant to Show Iran that Israel Could Paralyze Its Defenses
description: This attack used a fraction of the fire power Iran deployed last week when it launched hundreds of drones and missiles at Israel.
content: An Israeli airstrike on Iran on Friday damaged an air defense system, according to Western and Iranian officials, and appeared calculated to deliver a message that Israel could bypass Iran’s defensive systems undetected and paralyze them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Wheatley
title: That Time Europe Tried to Bring Monarchy Back to Mexico
description: In “Habsburgs on the Rio Grande,” Raymond Jonas’s story of French-backed nation building in Mexico foreshadows the proxy battles of the Cold War.
content: In October 1863, a Mexican delegation arrived in Trieste, a polyglot city in southern Europe on the borderlands of the Hapsburg Empire. In a turreted castle on the Adriatic coast, the delegates — many of them Europhile bankers and industrialists — offered the crown of Mexico to Maximilian, a Hapsburg prince, and his wife, Charlotte, daughter of the king of Belgium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Johnson, Like Pence, Draws Praise for Defying His Party and Doing His Job
description: In the Republican Party of 2024, styled in the image of former President Donald J. Trump, a norm-preserving, consensus-driven act — even a basic one — can be a career-ending offense.
content: The accolades directed at Speaker Mike Johnson in recent days for finally defying the right wing of his party and allowing an aid bill for Ukraine to move through the House might have seemed a tad excessive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: This Therapy Helps Victims of Violent Crime. Who Will Pay for It?
description: “Trauma recovery centers” are favored by law-and-order officials and progressive activists alike for one big reason: They work. But to stay open in New York, they need more funding.
content: Last spring, Randy White was shot in the stomach when he was caught in the crossfire of a gunfight at an Atlanta gas station. The injury kept him in the hospital for a week, but his mental state was paid little consideration. Discharged with no meaningful plan to deal with the psychological fallout that would inevitably come, he found himself adrift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Military Aid for Ukraine Could Soon Flow Again
description: What would $60 billion buy? Lots of air-defense missiles and artillery ammunition, according to the Pentagon.
content: Shipments of American weapons could begin flowing to Ukraine again soon after a long-stalled aid package becomes law, U.S. officials say, with goods from the Pentagon’s stockpiles in Germany to be shipped quickly by rail to the Ukrainian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Nevada G.O.P. Senate primary heats up as the long shot goes after the front-runner.
description: The Army veteran Sam Brown remains the favorite, but the wealthy former ambassador Jeff Gunter, with a pro-Trump message, is trying to shake up the race.
content: Nevada’s once-sleepy Republican primary for Senate, which has been dominated by Sam Brown, a U.S. Army veteran, was jolted to life in the past week, when a deep-pocketed rival took aim at the front-runner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Alfred Molina on the Museum He Never Misses When He’s in New York
description: “Every time I’m in the city, I make a visit,” said the actor, who is performing on Broadway in “Uncle Vanya.”
content: After more than 30 years in Los Angeles, Alfred Molina is enjoying his newly minted status as an Upper West Sider.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books That Capture New York
description: A stroll around the city with a great stylist; a comic novel of love and real estate.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Peter Morgan Turns His Pen From ‘The Crown’ to the Kremlin
description: His new play “Patriots,” now on Broadway, follows Putin’s rise to power and the Russian oligarchs who mistakenly thought he’d be their puppet.
content: Going from Princess Diana, a lovely icon who generated waves of sympathy, to Vladimir Putin, an icy villain who generates waves of disdain, might be difficult for some writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ex-Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Murder in Shooting of 12-Year-Old Boy
description: Edsaul Mendoza, a former Philadelphia police officer, could face up to 40 years in prison after pleading guilty to third-degree murder.
content: A former Philadelphia police officer pleaded guilty on Friday to third-degree murder in the shooting of a fleeing 12-year-old boy in 2022, according to the Philadelphia District Attorney’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Fears Over Iran Buoy Netanyahu at Home. For Now.
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, lost considerable support after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks on Israel. Tensions with Iran have helped him claw some of it back.
content: Since the Hamas-led attack on Israel last October, the deadliest in Israeli history, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s political future has seemed bleak, with critics blaming him for the security failure and his poll ratings plummeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Explosion Damages Iraqi Base Used by Iran-backed Group
description: It was unclear who carried out the attack in Babylon Province, south of Baghdad.
content: Iraq’s joint military command says one person was killed and eight were injured in an explosion early Saturday at a base used by an Iranian-backed armed group, Harakat al Nujaba, in Iraq’s Babylon Province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Capturing Special Moments, While Creating Inclusive Weddings
description: Shannon Collins, a “queer, awkward, anxious photographer,” wants to change the way disabled people are viewed, one picture at a time.
content: The last five years for Shannon Collins, a wedding photographer who identifies as nonbinary, have been filled with survival and self-discoveries, all while Mx. Collins, captured celebrants’ most intimate and revealing moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Could the Union Victory at VW Set Off a Wave?
description: Some experts say the outcome at a plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., may be organized labor’s most significant advance in decades. But the road could get rockier.
content: By voting to join the United Automobile Workers, Volkswagen workers in Tennessee have given the union something it has never had: a factory-wide foothold at a major foreign automaker in the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Approves $95 Billion Aid Bill for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
description: After months of delay at the hands of a bloc of ultraconservative Republicans, the package drew overwhelming bipartisan support, reflecting broad consensus.
content: The House voted resoundingly on Saturday to approve $95 billion in foreign aid for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, as Speaker Mike Johnson put his job on the line to advance the long-stalled aid package by marshaling support from mainstream Republicans and Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Lawsuit Puts Fresh Focus on Eric Hovde’s Comments About Older Voters
description: Pressed on his claims of 2020 election irregularities, the Republican candidate for Senate in Wisconsin has questioned the mental capacity of nursing home residents to vote.
content: Eric Hovde, the Republican banking executive challenging Senator Tammy Baldwin in Wisconsin, may be developing a problem with older voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Most Major Crimes Are Down. Why Are Assaults Up?
description: Homicides, rapes and shootings in New York City have decreased, but the number of assaults has remained stubbornly high.
content: Just before noon last Saturday, a 9-year-old girl was with her mother at Grand Central Terminal when a man strode up to the child and, without warning, punched her in the face, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Markley
title: A Planetary Crisis Awaits the Next President
description: The return of Trump to the White House would be disastrous for the planet.
content: In the 12 years it took me to write “The Deluge,” my novel of the climate crisis, I watched as chaotic weather, record temperatures and shocking political events outpaced my imagination. The book depicts the human tipping point, when the damage becomes irreversible and the foundations of our economy, our politics and our world begin to crack. The plot points I was concocting in 2010 would become a constant drumbeat of headlines into 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Charlotte de la Fuente
title: It Introduced Ozempic to the World. Now It Must Remake Itself.
description: Novo Nordisk’s factories work nonstop turning out Ozempic and Wegovy, its blockbuster weight-loss drugs, but the Danish company has far bigger ambitions.
content: Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen has a problem: Too many people want what he’s selling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman, Eric Schmitt and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Israel’s Strike on Iran Highlights Its Ability to Evade Tehran’s Air Defenses
description: The retaliatory attack damaged a defense system near Natanz, a city in central Iran that is critical to the country’s nuclear weapons program.
content: An Israeli airstrike on Iran on Friday damaged an air defense system, according to Western and Iranian officials, in an attack calculated to deliver a message that Israel could bypass Iran’s defensive systems undetected and paralyze them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Alexandra Berzon and Michael Gold
title: G.O.P. Intensifies Scrutiny of Voting: ‘We’re Keeping a Close Eye on You’
description: The Trump campaign and the Republican Party plan to dispatch over 100,000 volunteers and lawyers to monitor elections in battleground states — and work in concert with conservative activists.
content: On a Monday in mid-March, the Wisconsin Republican Party gathered about 50 conservative activists on a Zoom call to train them in how to become poll workers, helping oversee and monitor the casting and counting of votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Donald Trump’s rally in North Carolina is called off for weather.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump was due to hold a campaign rally on Saturday in Wilmington, N.C., in a battleground state that he won by just more than 1 percent of the vote in the 2020 presidential election. But it was called off late in the day because of weather.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump was due to hold a campaign rally on Saturday in Wilmington, N.C., in a battleground state that he won by just more than 1 percent of the vote in the 2020 presidential election. But it was called off late in the day because of weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 314
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: Review: In ‘Still,’ Confessions Doom Two Reunited Lovers
description: Despite a juicy premise, this Colt Coeur production, starring Tim Daly and Jayne Atkinson, never manages to take off.
content: In her essay “The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction,” the novelist Ursula K. Le Guin hymned the bag as the proper shape for stories: it “is full of beginnings without ends, of initiations, of losses, of transformations and translations, and far more tricks than conflicts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Takeaways From Our Chinese Swimming Investigation
description: A doping case involving Olympic swimmers has left unanswered questions and raised new concerns about the actions of a global antidoping regulator.
content: In the first days of 2021, seven months before the pandemic-delayed Tokyo Olympics, 23 of China’s best swimmers tested positive for the same banned drug at a domestic meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Martín González Gómez, Kayla Guo, Robert Jimison, Albert Sun and Karen Yourish
title: How the House Voted on Foreign Aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
description: Here’s how each member of the House voted on the foreign aid bills.
content: Here’s how each member of the House voted on the foreign aid bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia
title: Carbon Dioxide Levels Have Passed a New Milestone
description: There’s 50 percent more carbon dioxide in the air than before the Industrial Revolution.
content: There’s 50 percent more carbon dioxide in the air than before the Industrial Revolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Weiyi Cai
title: What’s Happening In Myanmar’s Civil War?
description: Questions you may have about the ongoing war in Myanmar, explained with graphics.
content: Questions you may have about the ongoing war in Myanmar, explained with graphics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Levy
title: A Cheat Sheet to the Middle East’s Web of Friends and Enemies
description: As the conflict between Israel and Hamas spills over, we sketched out a social network of the alliances and enmities at play.
content: As the conflict between Israel and Hamas spills over, we sketched out a social network of the alliances and enmities at play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Claire Hogan
title: Behind Our Investigation Into a Chinese Doping Case
description: Months before the Tokyo 2021 Olympics, 23 Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance. Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.
content: Months before the Tokyo 2021 Olympics, 23 Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance. Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha, Karen Hanley and Christy Harmon
title: Capturing the Celtics’ Tunnel Walk
description: Players from Boston’s team arrive at basketball’s most exclusive private runway.
content: Players from Boston’s team arrive at basketball’s most exclusive private runway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech, Nikolay Nikolov and Adam Ferguson
title: A Trip to the Front Lines of a Forgotten War
description: A new generation of democracy fighters has taken up arms in Myanmar. If they push into the nation’s heartland, the rebels could unseat a military that’s had the country in its grip for decades. Hannah Beech, a New York Times reporter, embedded with one of the rebel groups on the front lines in Karenni State, where resistance forces said they held more than 90 percent of the territory.
content: A new generation of democracy fighters has taken up arms in Myanmar. If they push into the nation’s heartland, the rebels could unseat a military that’s had the country in its grip for decades. Hannah Beech, a New York Times reporter, embedded with one of the rebel groups on the front lines in Karenni State, where resistance forces said they held more than 90 percent of the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Eshe Nelson and Charlotte de la Fuente
title: Inside Novo Nordisk’s Headquarters
description: Ozempic and Wegovy, the diabetes and weight-loss drugs, have soared to celebrity status in the U.S. But Novo Nordisk, the Danish company behind them, can’t make enough of them. The New York Times reporter Eshe Nelson went to the drugmaker’s headquarters to see how the company is transforming to deal with the global fame and demand.
content: Ozempic and Wegovy, the diabetes and weight-loss drugs, have soared to celebrity status in the U.S. But Novo Nordisk, the Danish company behind them, can’t make enough of them. The New York Times reporter Eshe Nelson went to the drugmaker’s headquarters to see how the company is transforming to deal with the global fame and demand.
source.name: The New York Times
